https://s3.amazonaws.com/prod-ucs-content-store-us-east/content/pii:S0021951716302810/STRIPIN/image/gif/5179c930b81e2e8381d017480f6ac18c/si9.gif si9 si9.gif gif 680 15 182 ALTIMG YJCAT 12276 S0021-9517(16)30281-0 10.1016/j.jcat.2016.11.027 Elsevier Inc. Fig. 1 (a) UV–vis absorption spectra of the dopamine-derived polymers and corresponding monomers in aqueous solution. The concentration of samples was 0.1gL−1. The inset of (a) represents digital images of solutions. (b) Diffuse reflectance UV–visible spectra (DR-UVS) of pDA–TiO2, pNE–TiO2, pNDA–TiO2, DA–TiO2, and TiO2 powder samples. Fig. 2 ATR-FTIR spectra of the free monomer, the monomer-complexed TiO2, and the polymer-complexed TiO2 for (a) DA, (b) NE, and (c) NDA. Fig. 3 (a, b) HR-TEM images of the pDA–TiO2 sample. (c–e) EELS mapping of Ti, C, and N in pDA–TiO2 (corresponding to panel b). (f, g) HR-TEM images of the pNE–TiO2 sample. (h–j) EELS mapping of Ti, C, and N in panel g. (k, l) HR-TEM images of the pNDA–TiO2 sample. (m–o) EELS mapping of Ti, C, and N in panel l. (p, q) HR-TEM images of the bare TiO2 sample. (r–t) EELS mapping of Ti, C, and N in panel q. Fig. 4 Time profiles of (a) the reductive removal of Cr(VI), (b) Cl− production from CCl4 degradation, (c) oxidative conversion of As(III) to As(V), and (d) H2O2 production using pDA–TiO2, pNE–TiO2, pNDA–TiO2, DA–TiO2, and TiO2 (0.5gL−1 each) under visible light irradiation (λ>420nm). The experimental conditions were (a) [Cr(VI)] i =200μM, pH i =3, initially Ar purged; (b) catalysts were photodeposited with Pt (1wt.%) before complexation with polymer, [CCl4] i =10mM, pH i =3, initially Ar purged; (c) [As(III)] i =300μM, pH i =9, air-equilibrated; (d) air-equilibrated water at pH 3. Fig. 5 The time-dependent concentration profiles of FFA, MB, AO7, and 4-CP with pDA–TiO2 under visible light irradiation (λ>420nm). The experimental conditions were [catalyst]=0.5gL−1, air-equilibrated, [FFA] i =100μM in 10mM phosphate buffer (pH 7), and [MB or AO7 or 4-CP] i =100μM, pH i =3. Fig. 6 Photoluminescence spectra of (a) pDA, (b) pNE, and (c) pNDA with addition of TiO2. The initial concentration of polymer was 0.33gL−1. (d) Stern–Volmer (S-V) plots for static quenching of pDA and pNE (0.33gL−1) by TiO2 (quencher, gL−1). Fig. 7 (a) Time profiles of photocurrent generated with pDA–TiO2, pNE–TiO2, pNDA–TiO2, DA–TiO2, and TiO2 electrodes and (b) electrochemical impedance spectroscopic Nyquist plots under visible light irradiation. The experimental conditions were [LiClO4]=10mM, pH i =3, visible light (λ>420nm) illumination at +0.5V (vs. Ag/AgCl), continuously Ar purged. (c) IPCE spectra of pDA–TiO2, pNE–TiO2, pNDA–TiO2, DA–TiO2, and TiO2 as a function of wavelength. The experimental conditions were the same as for photocurrent and EIS measurement, except incident light. TiO2 complexed with dopamine-derived polymers and the visible light photocatalytic activities for water pollutants Sujeong Kim a Gun-hee Moon a Gonu Kim a Unseock Kang b Hyunwoong Park b Wonyong Choi a ⁎ a Department of Chemical Engineering and Division of Environmental Science and Engineering, Pohang University of Science and Technology (POSTECH), Pohang 37673, Republic of Korea Department of Chemical Engineering and Division of Environmental Science and Engineering Pohang University of Science and Technology (POSTECH) Pohang 37673 Republic of Korea b School of Energy Engineering, Kyungpook National University, Daegu 41566, Republic of Korea School of Energy Engineering Kyungpook National University Daegu 41566 Republic of Korea ⁎ Corresponding author. Fax: +82 54 279 8299. Graphical abstract Visible light-induced chemical transformation using inexpensive photocatalytic materials has been proposed as an eco-friendly method for energy and environmental applications. In this work, we employed polymers of environmentally benign derivatives of dopamine (DA) as low-cost sensitizers of titania and systematically investigated their properties for the visible light photocatalytic transformation in aquatic environment. DA and its derivatives (norepinephrine and nitrodopamine) were chosen as monomers, and their polymers (pDA, pNE, and pNDA) were synthesized and subsequently complexed with TiO2. Visible light-induced catalytic transformations were successfully demonstrated for the reduction of Cr(VI) to Cr(III), dechlorination of CCl4, oxidation of As(III) to As(V), and H2O2 production via dioxygen reduction using polymer-complexed TiO2. pDA–TiO2 exhibited the highest activities, much higher than those of DA–TiO2 in all tested cases, which indicates that the polymerized form of DA forms a stronger and more efficient surface complex on the TiO2 surface for visible light sensitization. DA-derived polymers could efficiently transfer electrons to the TiO2 conduction band under visible light to initiate reductive transformations, whereas the oxidative transformation of organic substrates was largely inhibited because the organic polymer layer on TiO2 should scavenge any oxidizing radical species. pDA and pNE exhibited far higher activity than pNDA due to the extensive π electron delocalization induced by the 5,6-dihydroxyindole structure. This was also supported by the higher photon-to-current conversion and lower charge transfer resistance obtained with pDA–TiO2 and pNE–TiO2 (compared with pNDA–TiO2), which was observed with photoelectrochemical measurements. pDA should be an attractive visible light sensitizer for aquatic transformations. Keywords Visible light photocatalysts Dopamine-derived polymers Water treatment Polymer dye sensitization Catalytic transformation of aquatic pollutants 1 Introduction Photocatalytic water treatment using heterogeneous semiconductors has been considered as an eco-friendly technology [1–4]. TiO2 is one of the most investigated photocatalysts because of its low material cost, nontoxicity, and photochemical stability, but its relatively wide bandgap (3.0–3.2eV) limits the utilization of visible light photons. A variety of technologies have been developed to broaden the practical use of visible light utilization by wide-bandgap semiconductors (e.g., doping, dye sensitization, coupling with narrow-bandgap semiconductors) [5,6]. Dye sensitization has been extensively studied for this purpose, using various organic dyes and organometallic complexes [7,8]. Although dye sensitization is efficient in absorbing visible light, most dyes are not stable enough in the photoirradiated aqueous environment. In addition, many popular dyes (e.g., ruthenium bipyridyl complexes) contain toxic and expensive metal elements, which limits their practical use as well. On the other hand, ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) [9] induced by surface adsorbates such as EDTA [10], catechol [11], ascorbic acid [12], and glucose [13] has been also proposed as a method of visible light utilization, but the molecular adsorbates are easily decomposed after the charge transfer. Organic polymeric materials as a photosensitizer should be more stable against photodegradation than molecular sensitizers. They are cost-effective and eco-friendly materials without toxic metal elements, while their properties are easily tunable through changing the degree of polymerization or the functional groups. This study particularly pays attention to polydopamine (pDA), which is a synthetic polymer inspired by the structure of the adhesion protein of mussels. It can be synthesized easily through oxidative self-polymerization of dopamine (DA), which is a common eco-friendly material [14]. pDA can absorb a wide range of light including far visible light due to its polymeric π-conjugated structure, which makes it a polymer dye. While DA is known to form a LMCT complex on TiO2, which generates superoxide under visible light [15,16], few studies have investigated the pDA-sensitized system [17,18]. In previous studies, pDA was coated onto TiO2 electrodes to absorb visible light and applied to dye-sensitized solar cells or dye degradation. Very recently, pDA–TiO2 core–shell and pDA-nanosphere-modified TiO2 were introduced into a slurry photocatalytic system; however, dyes were only tested as a model substrate [19,20]. Those studies suggested the possible use of pDA as an organic dye; however, in-depth investigation of its photocatalytic applications has not been done. We report a systematic study of pDA-sensitized TiO2 as a catalyst for the photocatalytic transformation of aquatic pollutants. Related dopamine derivatives of (−)-norepinephrine (NE) and nitrodopamine (NDA) were chosen for comparison with DA to understand the structure–activity relation. The optical properties and charge transfer mechanisms of TiO2 complexed with polymers of DA, NE, and NDA were systematically investigated and discussed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals and catalyst preparation P25 (average surface area 50±15m2/g) was used as a base photocatalyst material throughout this work. Chemicals used in this study are the following: dopamine hydrochloride (DA, Aldrich), (−)-norepinephrine (NE, Aldrich), tris(hydroxymethyl)-aminomethane (Aldrich), chloroplatinic acid (H2PtCl6·H2O, Aldrich) as a platinum precursor, sodium dichromate dihydrate (Aldrich) as a Cr(VI) source, 1,5-diphenyl carbazide (DPC, Aldrich), acetone (Samchun), sulfuric acid (Aldrich), carbon tetrachloride (Samchun), sodium (meta)arsenite (Aldrich), ascorbic acid (Aldrich), molybdate reagent solution (Aldrich), sodium phosphate monobasic (Aldrich), sodium phosphate dibasic (Aldrich), N,N-diethyl-1,4-phenylene-diamine sulfate (DPD, Aldrich), lithium perchlorate (Aldrich), methanol (J. T. Baker), furfuryl alcohol (Aldrich), methylene blue (MB, Aldrich), acid orange 7 (AO7, Aldrich), 4-chlorophenol (4-CP, Aldrich), hydrochloric acid (Aldrich), perchloric acid (Aldrich), phosphoric acid (Aldrich), acetonitrile (J. T. Baker), and tetrabutylammonium hexafluorophosphate (Bu4NPF6, Aldrich). All reagents were used as received. Deionized ultrapure water (18MΩ cm) was prepared by a Barnstead purification system. Nitrodopamine (NDA) was prepared following the literature method, which reacted dopamine hydrochloride with sodium nitrite [21]. Surface complexation of the polymers of DA and DA derivatives with TiO2 was done by slightly modifying the previously reported method [14]. TiO2 (1gL−1) was added into the tris buffer (10mM, pH 8.5) containing a DA derivative (DA, NE, or NDA) whose concentration was adjusted at 0.05gL−1 (optimized between maximal visible light absorption and minimal blocking of the active site). The mixture was sonicated for 1h and then stirred for 12h. Under this condition, DA and NE underwent intramolecular cyclization to produce 5,6-dihydroxyindole, which was further polymerized to a dark brown melanin-like structure aggregated on TiO2 [22]. However, the nitro group of NDA was oxidized as 6,7-dihydroxy-4-nitro-2,3-dihydroindole and produced dark yellow aggregates on TiO2. The suspension was filtered and washed with deionized water several times; then the filtrate was dried in vacuum. DA–TiO2 was prepared following the same method at pH 3. Surface-platinized TiO2 (Pt/TiO2), with a typical Pt loading of 1wt.%, which was used in the CCl4 degradation test, was prepared by photodeposition [23] before surface complexation with the polymers. 2.2 Photocatalytic activity test The visible light activity of the prepared photocatalyst samples was measured for the reduction of Cr(VI) to Cr(III), the reductive degradation of CCl4, the oxidation of As(III) to As(V), and the reductive conversion of O2 to H2O2 as test reactions. For comparison, oxidative reactions such as dye (MB and AO7) discoloration, FFA degradation, and 4-CP degradation were also tested. The prepared catalyst was dispersed in deionized water (0.5gL−1) by simultaneous sonication and shaking for 1min in an ultrasonic cleaning bath. Photoirradiation started after 30min of adsorption equilibration. The aqueous suspension of the photocatalyst was continuously Ar-purged in a sealed reactor for the reduction of Cr(VI) and CCl4, whereas As(III) oxidation, H2O2 production, dye discoloration, FFA degradation, and 4-CP oxidation were carried out under air-equilibrated conditions. In the case of CCl4 degradation, an aliquot of CCl4 was injected into the reactor after purging because CCl4 is volatile. The pH of the solution was adjusted with HClO4 or NaOH standard solution. A 300-W Xe arc lamp (Oriel) equipped with a 10-cm IR water filter and a long-pass cutoff filter (λ>420nm) was used as a light source; then the filtered light was focused onto a 55-mL Pyrex reactor that contained 30mL of solution. The reactor was stirred magnetically during the reaction. 2.3 Characterization and analysis The molecular weights of pDA, pNE, and pNDA were measured by a gel permeation chromatographic (GPC) system using a mobile phase of tris buffer (10mM, pH 8.5) with a flow rate of 0.8mLmin−1 through TSKgel (GMPWXL 2ea 350×7.5mm) column. pDA and pNE were synthesized by the above-mentioned method without TiO2 and filtered before analysis (pore size ∼0.45μm). Cyclic voltammetry (CV) measurements for pDA were performed using potentiostat connected to a computer using a pDA-coated glassy carbon electrode, a Pt wire, and Ag/AgCl as working, counter, and reference electrodes. A 0.1M solution of Bu4NPF6 in anhydrous acetonitrile was used as an electrolyte and the experiments were conducted under Ar with a scan rate of 100mV/s. Diffuse reflectance UV–visible absorption spectra (DR-UVS) were obtained using a spectrophotometer (Shimadzu UV-2600) with an integrating sphere attachment, and BaSO4 was used as a reference material. The UV–visible absorption spectra of solutions were measured with another spectrophotometer (Agilent 8453). The functional groups of samples (powder form) were characterized by ATR-FTIR (Thermo Scientific Nicolet iS50 FT-IR/ATR) on a ZnSe crystal. The high-resolution transmission electron micrographs (HR-TEMs) and electron energy loss spectra (EELS) mapping of the polymer-coated and bare TiO2 were obtained using a Cs-corrected JEM-2200F microscope (at the National Institute for Nanomaterials Technology, Pohang, Korea). Static photoemission spectra were measured using a spectrofluorometer (HORIBA FluoroMax-4). The concentrations of Cr(VI), As(V), and H2O2 were determined using colorimetric methods that used DPC, molybdenum blue, and DPD reagent, respectively [24–26]. The color change during the experiment was monitored at 540nm (ε=4×104 Lmol−1 cm−1) for Cr(VI), 870nm (ε=19,550Lmol−1 cm−1) for As(V), and 551nm (ε=21,000Lmol−1 cm−1) for H2O2 using a UV–visible spectrophotometer (Libra S22, Biochrom). Quantitative analysis of Cl− was conducted using an ion chromatograph (IC, Dionex DX-120), equipped with a Dionex IonPac AS 23 (4×250mm) column and a conductivity detector. A binary mixture of 3.5mM Na2CO3 and 1mM NaHCO3 was used as an eluent. The color of the dyes was monitored by a UV–visible spectrophotometer (Agilent 8453). The monitored wavelength for MB is 663nm, whereas that for AO7 is 485nm. The concentration of FFA and 4-CP was measured using HPLC (Agilent 1260 Infinity) equipped with a diode array detector and a ZORBAX 300SB-C18 column (4.6mm×150mm) using a 1:9 (v/v) mixture of acetonitrile and 0.08% H2PO4. Photocurrent and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurements were carried out in a conventional three-electrode system connected to a computer-controlled potentiostat (Gamry, Reference 600). The photoelectrochemical (PEC) cell contained a photoanode, a coiled Pt wire, and a Ag/AgCl (saturated KCl) electrode as working, counter, and reference electrodes, respectively. The TiO2/FTO photoanode was fabricated by coating P25 on FTO by the doctor blade method [27]. Surface complexation of the DA-derived polymers on TiO2 was done by immersing the TiO2 electrode in each polymer precursor solution for 12h. The photocurrent and EIS were measured by applying a potential bias of +0.5V (vs. Ag/AgCl) in a 10mM LiClO4 solution as an electrolyte. The reactor was deaerated with Ar sparging for 30min before irradiation and during the measurement. The incident photon-to-current efficiencies (IPCE) were estimated in aqueous lithium perchlorate (purged with Ar for 1h) using a typical three-electrode configuration. Monochromatic light was obtained from a 300W xenon lamp (Newport Oriel) using a CS 130 monochromator with a 10nm bandpass, and the output power was measured with a silicon photodiode detector (Newport). The IPCE was then calculated from (1240× I ph)×100/(P light ×λ), where I ph (mAcm−2), P light (mWcm−2), and λ (nm) refer to the photocurrent density at +0.5V (vs. Ag/AgCl) (Ivium Stat), photon flux, and monochromatic wavelength, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Surface complexation of the dopamine-derived polymers on TiO2 and visible light absorption Surface complexation of pDA, pNE, and pNDA on TiO2 was achieved by in situ polymerization of their monomers in the presence of TiO2. The chemical and structural properties of three dopamine derivative monomers and their polymers are listed in Table 1 and Fig. S1 in the Supplementary Data [28–30]. NE and NDA carry a hydroxyl or a nitro group as a substituent in the side chain or ring structure of DA. Although the exact mechanism for pDA formation and the structure are still controversial [31], the monitored UV–vis absorbance spectra before and after the oxidative process of DA derivatives suggested successful polymerization (Fig. 1 a). The transparent solutions of DA and NE were transformed into black or brown solutions, which indicates the formation of polymeric products [17,22]. The bandgap of pDA was determined as 1.6eV (Fig. S2), which allows the absorption of visible light. The proposed structures for pDA and pNE are described in Fig. S1 [22]. A similar structural unit containing dihydroxyindole was suggested for both of them, but the presence of a hydroxyl group in the NE alkyl chain might limit the degree of intramolecular cyclization in pNE. On the other hand, it is noted that the absorption spectrum of the NDA solution was dramatically changed after the self-oxidation process. However, the peak shift and color change were mainly caused by the pH change, as observed in Fig. S3 in the Supplementary Data. At acidic pH, NDA exists as an undissociated form which has absorption maxima at 312 and 350nm. With increasing pH, NDA deprotonates one of its catechol hydroxyl groups and the absorption maximum is shifted to 423nm [32,33]. Previous studies reported that NDA first undergoes intramolecular cyclization to form 6,7-dihydroxy-4-nitro-2,3-dihydroindole and then this molecule reacts with another NDA to form a dimer as an intermediate of pNDA (see Fig. S1) [34,35]. The dimer structure, including OCO bonds, suppresses the extensive π electron delocalization that is observed in pDA through 5,6-dihydroxyindole structures, which limits the visible light absorption over 550nm in the case of pNDA. The characteristics of surface complexation were investigated by DR-UVS and ATR-FTIR spectroscopy. As shown in Fig. 1b, bare TiO2 hardly absorbed visible light at wavelengths longer than 400nm, whereas pDA–TiO2 and pNE–TiO2 showed a wide range of visible light absorption up to 800nm, suggesting the possibility of visible light sensitization through polymer surface complexation. The noticeable peak in pNDA (around 420nm) was observed even after it was combined with TiO2 (pNDA–TiO2), but its visible light absorption was much weaker than that of pDA–TiO2 and pNE–TiO2. On the other hand, Fig. 2 compares the FT-IR spectra of the free monomer, the monomer-complexed TiO2, and the polymer-complexed TiO2. (See Table S1 in the Supplementary Data for the detailed peak assignments of each monomer.) pDA–TiO2 and pNE–TiO2 exhibited nearly similar spectral shapes characterized by aromatic CC vibrations around 1493cm−1 and a broad 1290cm−1 owing to the stretching vibration of CO. These spectral features are consistent with the bonding configuration of chelating complexes through phenoxy groups on pDA–TiO2 and pNE–TiO2 [36]. However, the IR band of phenoxy groups quite shifted but still remained after the complexation, because those polymers have many phenoxy groups and only a few are involved in forming surface complexes through monodentate or bidentate binding. The primary amine bands around 1300–1340 and 1580–1630cm−1 disappeared after polymerization, since intramolecular cyclization transformed the amines into secondary amines or imines. The broad band around 1630cm−1 is ascribed to the scissoring vibration of surface-adsorbed water molecules. On the other hand, pNDA–TiO2 exhibited a totally different shape than pDA–TiO2 and pNE–TiO2 and retained several peaks of NDA, suggesting that pNDA kept the original structure of its monomer and did not involve a marked change in the structure (Fig. 2c). Direct evidence of surface complexation was obtained by TEM and EELS mapping. As shown in Fig. 3 , pDA–TiO2 clearly showed the amorphous carbon layer on the TiO2 surface, which was absent on bare TiO2. Carbon and nitrogen, which are contained in pDA, are distributed throughout the whole TiO2 surfaces, as shown in EELS images (Fig. 3c–e), whereas those element signals were largely absent on the bare TiO2 surface (Fig. 3r–t). The TEM and EELS mapping for pNE–TiO2 and pNDA–TiO2 also showed similar results (Fig. 3f–o). As with pDA–TiO2, thin layers of amorphous carbon were observed in EELS mapping images of pNE–TiO2, and pNDA–TiO2 also confirmed them. 3.2 Photocatalytic activity of TiO2 complexed with dopamine-derived polymers The photocatalytic transformation is mainly divided into two parts, reductive and oxidative pathways, which are induced by electron and hole transfer, respectively. In this work, the visible light activity of polymer–TiO2 complexes was tested for both reductive and oxidative conversions. For this purpose, we employed four photoactivity tests: (1) reduction of Cr(VI) to Cr(III), (2) reductive dechlorination of CCl4, (3) oxidation of As(III) to As(V), and (4) H2O2 production through O2 reduction. Hexavalent chromium is highly toxic and can be reduced to a less toxic and easily precipitable form, Cr(III), through the reaction [37] (1) 6 e - + 14 H + + Cr 2 O 7 2 - → 2 Cr 3 + + 7 H 2 O. Fig. 4 a shows that 200μM of Cr(VI) could mostly be removed within 60min in the presence of pDA–TiO2 under visible light irradiation, while it took a little longer with pNE–TiO2, and even longer with pNDA–TiO2. It is noted that bare TiO2 and DA monomer-complexed TiO2 (DA–TiO2) exhibited negligible activity, which indicates that visible light sensitization is enabled by the pDA–TiO2 complex, not DA–TiO2. This is clearly shown when the absorption spectra of pDA–TiO2 and DA–TiO2 in Fig. 1b are compared. pNE–TiO2 was similar to pDA–TiO2 in its visible light absorption. pNDA–TiO2 was less efficient in visible light absorption, which is consistent with the lower visible light activity of pNDA–TiO2 than of pDA–TiO2 and pNE–TiO2. For the second reaction, the reductive degradation of CCl4 was measured by monitoring the generation of Cl− ions (Fig. 4b) [38]: (2) e - + CCl 4 → CCl 3 + Cl - . For this test reaction, 1wt.% of platinum-deposited TiO2 instead of bare TiO2 was used as the substrate of the polymer complex to facilitate the charge separation, because no chloride was generated in the absence of Pt on TiO2. pDA–TiO2 and pNE–TiO2 showed higher reactivity than others, similarly to the case of Cr(VI) reduction. However, this case did not show much difference between DA–TiO2 and pDA–TiO2 probably owing to the existence of the Pt co-catalyst. The catalytic oxidation of DA to pDA normally occurred on the platinum electrode [39,40], which implies that the in situ catalytic polymerization of DA on Pt might happen during the sample preparation step of DA–Pt/TiO2. As for the oxidative transformation in which As(III) is oxidized to As(V) (a less toxic form and easily removable with adsorbents), the visible light activities of different catalyst samples exhibited a trend that is very similar to that for Cr(VI) reduction (see Fig. 4a and c). In the visible-light-sensitized system, the main oxidant of As(III) has been proposed as superoxide that is generated by electron transfer: (3) e - + O 2 → O 2 - . The superoxide subsequently oxidizes As(III) to As(V) [41–43]: (4) O 2 - + As ( III ) + H + → As ( IV ) + HO 2 - , (5) As ( IV ) + O 2 → As ( V ) + HO 2 / O 2 - . Since both Cr(VI) reduction and As(III) oxidation are initiated by electron transfer, it is reasonable that the reactivity trends are similar in the two cases. In a similar context, the production of H2O2 through the reduction of O2 can represent the photocatalytic activity as an alternative test reaction. As shown in Fig. 4d, the activities for H2O2 production were generally similar to those for other test reactions. pDA–TiO2 and pNE–TiO2 were more active than pNDA–TiO2, and DA–TiO2 and bare TiO2 showed negligible activity. The concentrations of generated H2O2 were eventually saturated, since the reaction reached an equilibrium between production and decomposition [44–46]. H2O2 can be degraded via both oxidative and reductive paths: (6) O 2 + 2 H + + 2 e - → H 2 O 2 , (7a) H 2 O 2 + 2 ( polymer radical + ) → 2 H + + O 2 , (7b) H 2 O 2 + 2 H + + 2 e - → 2 H 2 O. DA could be adsorbed easily on the TiO2 surface through forming a LMCT complex, changing the color of the catalyst. As a result, visible-light-induced charge transfer occurs on DA–TiO2. When the visible light activity is compared between DA–TiO2 and pDA–TiO2, the activity of pDA–TiO2 is much higher than that of DA–TiO2 in all tested cases (Fig. 4), which indicates that the polymerized form of DA forms a stronger and more efficient LMCT complex on the TiO2 surface. The oxidation of As(III) and the production of H2O2 implies the generation of superoxide in the polymer-complexed TiO2 system. In addition, the polymer radicals can be generated immediately upon the injection of electrons into TiO2 under visible light, which can be further decomposed or regenerated by electron-donating species. The turnover numbers (TONs) for the activity tests (Fig. 4) were calculated on the basis of the measured molecular weight of polymers (M n), and the results are listed in Table 2 . After 1h of visible light irradiation, TONs for all test conversions are far higher than 1, which confirms the catalytic nature of the polymer-sensitized conversions under visible light. pNE–TiO2 exhibited much higher TONs than others because of the high molecular weight (M n) of pNE. To further test the possibility of generating other reactive oxygen species (ROS), several probe substrates were tested as well. Dye discoloration is the most common method of photocatalytic activity assessment. We selected MB (cationic dye) and AO7 (anionic dye) as test dyes. Fig. 5 shows that pDA–TiO2 has no activity for dye degradation. It also showed no or minor activity for the transformation of FFA (a common probe for 1O2) [47] and 4-CP (a probe for OH) [48], which indicates that the generation of 1O2 and OH should be insignificant in the present system of pDA–TiO2/visible light. Considering that H2O2 was generated under visible light irradiation of pDA–TiO2 (see Fig. 4d), the generation of OH radicals through the decomposition of H2O2 ( H 2 O 2 + e - → OH + OH - ) might be possible. However, the negligible activity for the degradation of organic substrates implies that this pathway, if any, seems to make an insignificant contribution. pDA–TiO2 does not seem to have any meaningful activity for the oxidative degradation of organic substrates. Since the surface of TiO2 is coated with the organic polymer layer, any oxidizing species, if any, might be immediately scavenged by the organic polymer layer itself. 3.3 Visible-light-sensitized charge transfer mechanisms When the polymer–TiO2 complex is irradiated with visible light, electrons are transferred from the polymer to TiO2. In a typical dye–TiO2, which is the donor–acceptor system, the charge transfer to TiO2 can be monitored by fluorescence quenching of dyes. A dynamic quenching model that follows a linear Stern–Volmer (S-V) plot, (8) I 0 I = 1 + K SV [ Q ] , where I and I 0 represent PL intensity with and without quencher, K SV is the S-V constant and [Q] is the concentration of quencher; in this case, TiO2 is generally applied in a majority of cases. The photoemission changes of pDA and pNE upon addition of TiO2 were monitored and Fig. 6 a and b shows that the emission intensity gradually decreases with increasing quencher (TiO2) concentration. Corresponding S-V plots for pDA and pNE are shown in Fig. 6d. The nonlinear plot indicates that the charge transfer mechanism from pDA (or pNE) to TiO2 cannot be explained solely by a dynamic or collisional quenching model. The positive deviation from linearity indicates the existence of static quenching, which means that pDA and pNE are chemically bound to the TiO2 surface and the excited state of the polymer dye is efficiently quenched by contacting TiO2 and only a fraction of the excited state is quenched by a collisional process [49]. Therefore, it also supports the successful formation of a charge transfer complex. The fact that the PL intensity of pNDA did not fit into the typical S-V plot suggests that TiO2 is not an efficient quencher for the excited state of pNDA (Fig. 6c). Its PL intensity was not markedly reduced by the presence of TiO2, indicating inefficient electron transfer from pNDA to TiO2. This could be one reason for the inferior visible light activity of pNDA–TiO2 compared with pDA–TiO2 and pNE–TiO2. The detailed charge transfer mechanisms for dye sensitization and LMCT are illustrated in Scheme 1 . Since the HOMO–LUMO gap of dopamine (DA) is 4.4eV [50], only direct electron transfer from DA HOMO to TiO2 CB is allowed under visible light. However, the bandgap of pDA is markedly reduced, enabling the excitation of pDA itself by visible light and the subsequent transfer of electrons to TiO2. CB facilitates the reductive conversion reactions occurring on the TiO2 surface. The charge transfer behavior was investigated through several photoelectrochemical measurements (Fig. 7 ). TiO2/FTO electrodes coated with the DA-derived polymer were used as photoanodes in a three-electrode system. The generation of photocurrent on the photoanodes represents electron transfer from the excited polymer to TiO2. The photocurrents obtained with pDA–TiO2 and pNE–TiO2 electrodes were much higher than those of pNDA–TiO2 and DA–TiO2 electrodes, which is consistent with the photocatalytic activity trend (e.g., Fig. 4a vs. Fig. 7a). In addition, as shown in Fig. 7b, the interfacial electron transfer was more facile with pDA–TiO2 and pNE–TiO2 than with bare TiO2, showing smaller arcs in EIS Nyquist plots, which indicate the smaller resistance in interfacial charge transfer. In particular, pDA–TiO2 having the smallest arc is consistent with the fact that pDA–TiO2 exhibited the highest activities for all the visible-light-induced transformations (Fig. 4), which are initiated by photoinduced electron transfer. On the other hand, although the light absorption of pDA–TiO2 and pNE–TiO2 reached up to 800nm, the IPCE values are largely limited below 500nm, which indicates that the absorbed visible light in the longer-wavelength region did not induce successful charge separation (Fig. 7c). However, pDA–TiO2 and pNE–TiO2 yielded higher IPCE values than others in the visible light region, which is also consistent with other photocatalytic and PEC measurements. 4 Conclusions This study broadens the application of pDA as an efficient photosensitizer to photocatalytic environmental remediation besides other applications as common surface functionalizer for hydrogels, Li-ion batteries, electrocatalysts, bioimaging, and sensors. The preparation of polymer–TiO2 could be done easily by auto-oxidation of dopamine derivatives in an alkaline TiO2 slurry in a one-step process. pDA absorbs a considerable amount of visible light by itself due to its π-conjugated structure; however, the structural divergence in chain and ring substitution of DA led to alteration in polymerization structures and properties, as observed with other derivatives such as NE and NDA. Although the hydroxyl group in NE hardly affects the photocatalytic activity, the nitro group in NDA notably influences the activity due to the structure-induced limitation of visible light absorption. Concerning the efficiency of the dopamine-derived polymers on TiO2 in various photocatalytic reactions, it is concluded that the reductive conversion reactions through CB electron transfer can be favorably achieved under visible light, whereas the oxidative counterparts are hardly achievable. Polymer dyes derived from environmentally benign dopamine derivatives are expected to be applied further to various photocatalytic and photoelectrochemical systems due to their simplicity in preparation and a wide variety of selections in inexpensive and easily available polyphenols. (2009-0093880) funded by the Korean Government (MSIP) through the National Research Foundation of Korea (NRF). coredata.dc:description: Visible light-induced chemical transformation using inexpensive photocatalytic materials has been proposed as an eco-friendly method for energy and environmental applications. In this work, we employed polymers of environmentally benign derivatives of dopamine (DA) as low-cost sensitizers of titania and systematically investigated their properties for the visible light photocatalytic transformation in aquatic environment. DA and its derivatives (norepinephrine and nitrodopamine) were chosen as monomers, and their polymers (pDA, pNE, and pNDA) were synthesized and subsequently complexed with TiO2. Visible light-induced catalytic transformations were successfully demonstrated for the reduction of Cr(VI) to Cr(III), dechlorination of CCl4, oxidation of As(III) to As(V), and H2O2 production via dioxygen reduction using polymer-complexed TiO2. pDA–TiO2 exhibited the highest activities, much higher than those of DA–TiO2 in all tested cases, which indicates that the polymerized form of DA forms a stronger and more efficient surface complex on the TiO2 surface for visible light sensitization. DA-derived polymers could efficiently transfer electrons to the TiO2 conduction band under visible light to initiate reductive transformations, whereas the oxidative transformation of organic substrates was largely inhibited because the organic polymer layer on TiO2 should scavenge any oxidizing radical species. pDA and pNE exhibited far higher activity than pNDA due to the extensive π electron delocalization induced by the 5,6-dihydroxyindole structure. This was also supported by the higher photon-to-current conversion and lower charge transfer resistance obtained with pDA–TiO2 and pNE–TiO2 (compared with pNDA–TiO2), which was observed with photoelectrochemical measurements. pDA should be an attractive visible light sensitizer for aquatic transformations.
coredata.dc:title: TiO2 complexed with dopamine-derived polymers and the visible light photocatalytic activities for water pollutants
